wp:tag.wp:tag_name: but online. Youâ€™ll need the right credentials (experience

wp:term.wp:term_description: Recipient was mentioned in an activity update.
A member has replied to an activity update that the recipient posted.
A member has replied to a comment on an activity update that the recipient posted.
A site member has sent a site invitation to the recipient.
Recipient has successfully activated an account.
Recipient has registered for an account.
Recipient has registered for an account and site.
A member has sent a friend request to the recipient.
Recipient has had a friend request accepted by a member.
Recipient was mentioned in a group activity update.
A member has sent a group invitation to the recipient.
Recipient's status within a group has changed.
A member has requested permission to join a group.
Recipient had requested to join a group, which was accepted.
Recipient had requested to join a group, which was rejected.
Recipient has received a private message.
A member has unread private messages.
Recipient has changed their email address.

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] {{poster.name}} replied to one of your updates
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:
{{poster.name}} replied to one of your updates:
"{{usermessage}}"
Go to the discussion to reply or catch up on the conversation.

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] Activate your account
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: Thanks for registering! To complete the activation of your account, go to the following link and click on the Activate button: {{{activate.url}}} If the 'Activation Key' field is empty, copy and paste the following into the field - {{key}}

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] Activate {{{user-site.url}}}
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: Thanks for registering! To complete the activation of your account and site, go to the following link: {{{activate-site.url}}}. After you activate, you can visit your site at {{{user-site.url}}}.

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] Activate your account
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: Thanks for registering! To complete the activation of your account, go to the following link and click on the Activate button: {{{activate.url}}} If the 'Activation Key' field is empty, copy and paste the following into the field - {{key}}

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] Activate {{{user-site.url}}}
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: Thanks for registering! To complete the activation of your account and site, go to the following link: {{{activate-site.url}}}. After you activate, you can visit your site at {{{user-site.url}}}.

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] New friendship request from {{initiator.name}}
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: {{initiator.name}} wants to add you as a friend. To accept this request and manage all of your pending requests, visit: {{{friend-requests.url}}}

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] {{friend.name}} accepted your friendship request
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: {{friend.name}} accepted your friend request.
item.excerpt:encoded:
{{friend.name}} accepted your friend request.
To learn more about them, visit their profile: {{{friendship.url}}}

{{changed_text}}

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] You have an invitation to the group: "{{group.name}}"
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: {{inviter.name}} has invited you to join the group: "{{group.name}}". {{invite.message}} Go here to accept your invitation or visit the group to learn more.

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] You have been promoted in the group: "{{group.name}}"
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: You have been promoted to {{promoted_to}} in the group "{{group.name}}".
item.excerpt:encoded:
You have been promoted to {{promoted_to}} in the group: "{{group.name}}".
To visit the group, go to: {{{group.url}}}

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] Membership request for group: {{group.name}}
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: {{requesting-user.name}} wants to join the group "{{group.name}}". {{request.message}} As you are an administrator of this group, you must either accept or reject the membership request. Go here to manage this and all other pending requests.

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] New message from {{sender.name}}
item.dc:creator: MetaFans

item.title: [{{{site.name}}}] Verify your new email address
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: You recently changed the email address associated with your account on {{site.name}} to {{user.email}}. If this is correct, go here to confirm the change. Otherwise, you can safely ignore and delete this email if you have changed your mind, or if you think you have received this email in error.
item.excerpt:encoded:
You recently changed the email address associated with your account on {{site.name}} to {{user.email}}. If this is correct, go to the following link to confirm the change: {{{verify.url}}}
Otherwise, you can safely ignore and delete this email if you have changed your mind, or if you think you have received this email in error.

Otherwise, you can safely ignore and delete this email if you have changed your mind, or if you think you have received this email in error.

item.title: New Post
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:
Write New Post

Start a conversation, ask a question or share your idea.

Visit the Help Center for MetaFans technical or platform support questions.

Tips on Posting

  • Be as specific as possible in your post title, so other instructors know what you have a question about or want to discuss.
  • Pick the most relevant forum for your post. If youâ€™re not sure, make your best guess. A moderator can move the post for you if thereâ€™s a better space for it.
  • Limit the number of photos, videos, and GIFs you include in one post. Too many visuals may make the page slow to load.
  • Read the latest news and announcements from MetaFans, and learn how to use the Instructor Community.

item.title: Learn the Secrets of Online Community Management from Mozâ€™s
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:
What is an Online Community?

An online community is a group of people who interact with each other on an online platform. These communities can range from the 1+ billion-person Instagram community to a 10-person community of coffee lovers that rates artisan cafes in their city through a private Facebook group.

Thereâ€™s a huge range in how an online community can scale, and understanding what type of online community is the most beneficial for your brand is the first step in building your own community.

Types of Online Communities

The type of online community that you choose to create is going to be the answer to the above question, what community does your customer want? Your artisan coffee community doesnâ€™t want to share their coffee tasting experiences with 1+ billion people. They want an intimate group of coffee lovers who know what theyâ€™re talking about and have a similar palette.

On the flip side, bloggers making a full-time living sharing their lifestyle are more than happy to try to grow their brandâ€™s community as large as possible within the massive Instagram community of 1+ billion users.

There are two types of online communities:

1. Public social networks.

Think Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, TikTokâ€”even Vine (RIP) was a massive online community. Public social networks are online communities that only require someone to have an account to be part of the community. There arenâ€™t many guidelines or restrictions when it comes to who gets to be part of this type of community.

2. Branded communities.

This type of community is the opposite of a public social network. Youâ€™ll need to provide more than an email address and password to get inside of the community. Imagine SOHO house, or a private members club, but online. Youâ€™ll need the right credentials (experience, common interests, location, etc.) to have access to the communityâ€”even if itâ€™s on a public social media platform.

item.title: The importance of motivation in open source communities
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:

The type of online community that you choose to create is going to be the answer to the above question, what community does your customer want? Your artisan coffee community doesnâ€™t want to share their coffee tasting experiences with 1+ billion people. They want an intimate group of coffee lovers who know what theyâ€™re talking about and have a similar palette.

On the flip side, bloggers making a full-time living sharing their lifestyle are more than happy to try to grow their brandâ€™s community as large as possible within the massive Instagram community of 1+ billion users.

There are two types of online communities:

1. Public social networks.

Think Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, TikTokâ€”even Vine (RIP) was a massive online community. Public social networks are online communities that only require someone to have an account to be part of the community. There arenâ€™t many guidelines or restrictions when it comes to who gets to be part of this type of community.

2. Branded communities.

This type of community is the opposite of a public social network. Youâ€™ll need to provide more than an email address and password to get inside of the community. Imagine SOHO house, or a private members club, but online. Youâ€™ll need the right credentials (experience, common interests, location, etc.) to have access to the communityâ€”even if itâ€™s on a public social media platform.
item.excerpt:encoded: Thereâ€™s a huge range in how an online community can scale, and understanding what type of online community is the most beneficial for your brand is the first step in building your own community.

item.title: A new era for international associations â€“ there is no turning!
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:
What is an Online Community?

An online community is a group of people who interact with each other on an online platform. These communities can range from the 1+ billion-person Instagram community to a 10-person community of coffee lovers that rates artisan cafes in their city through a private Facebook group.

Thereâ€™s a huge range in how an online community can scale, and understanding what type of online community is the most beneficial for your brand is the first step in building your own community.

Types of Online Communities

The type of online community that you choose to create is going to be the answer to the above question, what community does your customer want? Your artisan coffee community doesnâ€™t want to share their coffee tasting experiences with 1+ billion people. They want an intimate group of coffee lovers who know what theyâ€™re talking about and have a similar palette.

On the flip side, bloggers making a full-time living sharing their lifestyle are more than happy to try to grow their brandâ€™s community as large as possible within the massive Instagram community of 1+ billion users.

There are two types of online communities:

1. Public social networks.

Think Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, TikTokâ€”even Vine (RIP) was a massive online community. Public social networks are online communities that only require someone to have an account to be part of the community. There arenâ€™t many guidelines or restrictions when it comes to who gets to be part of this type of community.

2. Branded communities.

This type of community is the opposite of a public social network. Youâ€™ll need to provide more than an email address and password to get inside of the community. Imagine SOHO house, or a private members club, but online. Youâ€™ll need the right credentials (experience, common interests, location, etc.) to have access to the communityâ€”even if itâ€™s on a public social media platform.
item.excerpt:encoded: Thereâ€™s a huge range in how an online community can scale, and understanding what type of online community is the most beneficial for your brand is the first step in building your own community.

item.content:encoded: I finished the Google IT Support program a couple of weeks ahead of schedule. I work 6 days/50 hours a week, and Iâ€™m taking online classes at the local community college in pursuit of a degree in Computer Science. Consistently setting aside, and adhering to, scheduled time for classwork is very important. The way each weekly lesson was broken down into smaller sub sections made it easy to complete. My preferred method was to set aside a 2-3 undisturbed hours and complete each weekly lesson all at once.

item.title: How to Choose the Best Domain Name (Tips and Tools)
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:
Choosing the right domain name for your website is crucial for your success. If you choose the wrong domain name, then it can be a hassle to switch later on without hurting your brand and search rankings.

Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s extremely important that you choose the best domain name from the start. When first starting out, it can be hard to come up with catchy business name ideas with a perfect domain name.

In this article, weâ€™ll share all the tools and tips you need to get domain name ideas, choose the best domain name, and register your new domain (for free).

item.title: In a Professional Certificate program? Introduce yourself here! [April 2021]
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:
The Professional Certificate Community is a place to connect with other people in your same Professional Certificate program (or a different one)! Youâ€™re also welcome here if youâ€™re thinking about doing a Professional Certificate and have questions. The more the merrier! Weâ€™d love to get to know you a bit better, so please introduce yourself! Here are some things you may want to include:
  • Where you're from or where you live now
  • Which Professional Certificate youâ€™re doing
  • What you want to do with your new knowledge/skills
  • What your hobbies or interests are
  • What youâ€™d like to get out of this community

item.title: Have you completed a Professional Certificate?
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: If youâ€™ve completed a Professional Certificate - Congratulations!ðŸ¥³ðŸŽ‰ It takes time, effort, and perseverance to reach the finish line and not everyone can do it. If you have completed one, Iâ€™d love to know how you managed your time and how you kept yourself motivated until the end. Iâ€™m guessing your stories will be helpful for others who are currently working through a Professional Certificate and maybe finding it challenging.

item.title: Would you like to find a study buddy or group?
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded:
A big reason we created this community space is so you could connect with other people learning on MetaFans. We know it's not always easy to find each other, especially if you aren't in the same course session. Inspired by @Jessey M's post, "How can I find people taking the same courses in same area for a study group?," I want to ask you all this question.
When we have a global community like this and over 3,000 courses in theÂ catalog, it's such a good question. How do you find people in your area taking the same courses?

Please help :)

item.title: What makes you a good higher education teacher?
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: My teaching approach combines both Ex-Cathedra and Interactive teaching methods. At the early stage of each course, I present a very structured overview of the subject and the study plan. I emphasize that the course materials are just one appropriate solution to the research problem. In this context, I plan to start each course by inviting a librarian to instruct students on using search engines to find articles relevant to the subject. At the later stages, I use interaction activities in the class that keeps students interested and engaged. These activities may include the use of multimedia, short videos, studentsâ€™ votes during the class. Making a personal connection with students is also important to me. I use my own human experience to shape my philosophy of dealing with students and influence my actions, inside and outside the classroom. I fully understand that different students learn in different ways. Small details interest some students, while others are more interested in overviews. Some students prefer working in teams and others prefer working individually. I consider these differences among students by remaining observant and flexible. Evaluating the progress of students towards the course goals will be done through several assignments, presentations, and final examinations. Regular feedback from students, through assignments and presentations, enables me and students to quickly identify areas in which they are excelling or having difficulty. In addition, in-class discussions with students provide me with immediate feedback and therefore I may either move through the material more rapidly or revisit particular points. Finally, for fairness to prevail in student evaluation, I would invite external experts to the evaluation of the final exam.

item.title: Warning Note for Envato Elements Sellers !!
item.dc:creator: MetaFans
item.content:encoded: Okay! Since the last day we are dealing with several reports regarding misleading sales, thread titles including taking payments in advance from buyers in name of 60 days / 90 days customers. Even one of our staff members appeared to be the victim of it... HENCE! All the Envato Elements sellers should abide by the following rules: Thread title + contents + refund policy should strictly be limited to only "30 days account" which Envato officially offers via giveaway. Everything A-Z should be clearly stated to the interested buyers before proceeding with the sale. There should no way be any kind of 60 days / 90 days or so on kind of shits, or taking payments in advance by any kind of excuses like "pay extra, I will renew next month free" etc blah blah blah. Nothing nowhere, even by directing customers to other platforms for deals. Means should be only 30 days sells by maintaining all the required ruleset policies. I (including other staff members) will mention a few seller's names here to give them a warning in advance... All the mentioned as well as other selling thread holders should edit their thread as soon as possible. After being active, and neglecting this warning will simply lead us to click some random buttons beside your profile name to make you guys disappear from here (get it clear what I mean) . . . That's all . . Violating will cause the profile to be Banned permanently, even if we find multiple violations we will Blacklist/prohibit Envato elements selling just like cracked Netflix, Edu based google drive sells. TO REFRAIN THE THREAD FROM UNNECESSARY DISCUSSIONS IT WILL REMAIN CLOSED WHILE MENTIONING SELLERS BY MODS WILL GO ON . . .
